webTitle: Inmarsat flies high on hopes for resolution to US agreement

fields.standfirst: Reports of possible deal for US partner LightSquared's spectrum could benefit UK satellite group
fields.body:
Inmarsat is flying high despite uncertainty about the future of a key US agreement.

The satellite communications specialist, which recently warned it had been hit by US government budget cuts, has climbed 31.5p to 697.5p after a buy note from Jefferies.

But news overnight of a possible buyout of the spectrum assets of bankrupt US group LightSquared could have an impact on Inmarsat. Satellite company Dish Networks has reportedly offered to buy LightSquared's wireless airwaves for around $2bn.

Inmarsat has a cooperation agreement with LightSquared to enable the re-banding and efficient reuse of Inmarsat's L-band radio spectrum covering North America, but there has been a moratorium on the deal since May 2012 when LightSquared, which was funded by hedge fund specialist Philip Falcone, declared bankruptcy.

Any change of ownership of the spectrum could potentially change the arrangement between LightSquared and Inmarsat. Giles Thorne at Jefferies said:

There will be a lot of speculation as to the read-across to Inmarsat from the overnight news. It is far from clear cut in our view. A bull case for Inmarsat would argue that if Dish was to purchase LightSquared's spectrum, then the co-operation agreement would pass over to Dish and there would be a chance that payments to Inmarsat under the agreement would ultimately begin again (i.e. why would Dish be buying spectrum they felt they couldn't use?).
Equally, the bear case for Inmarsat would argue that if the Dish purchase proceeds either it buys just the spectrum and not the business (meaning the co-operation agreement won't pass over, though admittedly this scenario feels less likely) or it shelves the cooperation agreement because it has enough spectrum from its recent purchases (Terrestar, potentially Clearwire) that they no longer need Inmarsat's spectrum. We have spoken to the company this morning and they are unwilling/unable to strongly steer on what the implications are, feeling that it is just too speculative at this point.

webTitle: FTSE heads for new 13 year high, but Carnival sinks 13% after warning on earnings

fields.standfirst: Cruise company suffers after cutting ticket prices to encourage customers following high profile problems
fields.body:
Leading shares are heading for a new (near) 13 year high following a revival in mining shares and a spate of positive company updates.

But cruise company Carnival is sinking fast after it issued a profit warning overnight. The trouble hit-company cut its earnings outlook for the second time in three months, as it cut ticket prices to attract customers following a series of high profile problems.

Since the beginning of 2012, when one of its ships capsized off the Italian coast killing 32 people, other vessels have run into trouble, including the Carnival Triumph drifting for five days in the Gulf of Mexico without electricity or sufficient sanitation.

The company said it now expects earnings per share to be between $1.45 and $1.65 compared to previous guidance of $1.80 to $2.10. As well as reduced ticket prices, the company pointed to increased voyage cancellations.

Carnival's shares are the biggest faller in the FTSE 100, down 314p at £20.96, a 13% decline.

James Hollins at Investec Securities said:

We had been over-optimistic in our view that Carnival could produce a solid 2013 outturn post the Carnival Triumph issues (we had assumed net yield growth of 1% for 2013). Although our outlook beyond 2013 assumes a strong rebound, our price target falls from 2,800p to 2,550p and faith needs to be restored in Carnival's ability to improve yields from 2014.

Panmure Gordon issued a sell note, with analyst Karl Burns saying:

The reduction is primarily due to lower net revenue yield guidance of down 2%-3% compared to previous expectations of flat. This reflects significant price reductions which have not been offset by a high enough increase in volumes. This bodes ill for the future as we think Carnival will struggle to regain pricing power.

Overall the FTSE 100 has added another 12.58 points to 6768.21, its best level since September 2000, helped by a recovery in the mining sector after recent weakness. Precious metals specialist Polymetal is up 32p at 649p, while Glencore Xstrata has added 13p to 347.95p.

The current run has been mainly driven by central banks taking action to boost the global economy, and there is some caution about what happens when the taps are turned off. Various US Federal Reserve members have been hinting at a possible end to its bond buying programme. Jonathan Sudaria at Capital Spreads said:

Speculation surrounding QE should be given some clarity this week as Federal Reserve Chairman Bernanke speaks and FOMC minutes are released.

Among companies reporting, Marks & Spencer has climbed 20.5p to 461p despite full year profits falling from £687.2m to £665.2m, its second straight decline. But the figure was in line with analysts expectations. As predicted, clothing sales proved a drag on the business but food revenues continued to grow.

Burberry is 25p better at £14.88 as the luxury goods group reported a better than expected 14% rise in profits to £428m, thanks to strong growth in Asia. Allegra Perry at Cantor Fitzgerald said:

This is a solid set of results with a strong operational performance illustrating the group is executing well on its strategic objectives, with the brand well-positioned for profitable growth, in our view. Despite a strong performance, Burberry's operating margin (21.4%) remains well shy of key competitors such as PPR's Gucci (operating margin 31%), suggesting significant upside potential in our view. The stock trades on a rolling 12 month forward PE of 18.4 times, which is around 7% above its historical average, and broadly in line with the luxury sector average. While we do not view this as a demanding multiple, considering the company's growth prospects, we maintain a hold recommendation on the stock to reflect continued uneven trading which we see as risky.

Vodafone has edged 0.05p higher at 197.65p as operating profits came in better than expected, up 9.3% at £12bn despite weakness in its European businesses. But it has decided to keep a £2.1bn dividend payment from US joint venture Verizon Wireless rather than returning it to shareholders.

Capita has climbed to the top of the FTSE 100, up 69p to £10.18 after it announced a 10 year deal to manage O2's customer service centres. The contract is expected to be worth around £1.2bn and will start in July. With recent contracts now totalling £2bn the company has raised its guidance for the full year and now expects at least 8% organic growth.

webTitle: Vodafone reports first ever fall in revenues as southern Europe slumps

fields.bodyText: Vodafone has recorded its first ever fall in annual revenues after the recession in southern Europe caused its income there to dip by almost 17%. With its finances under pressure, the British mobile phone company said it would reinvest next month's £2.1bn dividend from US subsidiary Verizon Wireless in the business rather than return cash to shareholders. Overall revenues fell 4.2% to £44.4bn, marking the first such contraction since Vodafone was spun off from Racal as an independent company on the London and New York stock exchanges in 1991. Tuesday's results also marked the largest fall in organic service revenue since the measure was introduced in 2003. It counts income from calls but excludes handset sales and takes into account mergers and disposals, and currency changes. The company wrote down the value of its businesses by £1.8bn, bringing to £7.7bn the reduction in book value of its operations in Italy and Spain this year. Amid the financial gloom, Vodafone has delayed plans to switch on 4G in Britain, saying it wants to ensure its network will be ready. The service, for which Vodafone spent £790m on spectrum in February's government airwaves auction, had been expected to go live in May or June, but will now come at the end of the summer. "We have faced headwinds from a combination of continued tough economic conditions, particularly in southern Europe, and an adverse European regulatory environment," said the Vodafone chief executive, Vittorio Colao. Regulation has been gradually reducing the cost of connections to mobile phones in recent years, bringing down service revenues for operators. Colao gave no update on Vodafone's discussions over selling all or part of the 45% stake in its US network to co-owner Verizon Communications. Investor hopes of a big dividend from a potential $130bn (£85bn) cash and shares deal have boosted Vodafone shares in recent months. "If an offer comes that is more advantageous than the current situation of course we will be open to it," said Colao. Analyst Jerry Dellis at Jefferies bank said the decision not to return any of the Verizon dividend to shareholders was "disappointing and a break with previous policy". There have been suggestions Verizon Communications, which has the power to veto payouts from their shared mobile business, could block further dividends this year as it attempts to wrest control of the asset. Vodafone's ordinary final dividend will rise to 6.92p, a 7% increase this year and a 22% increaserise over the past three years. The firm said it would "at least maintain" the ordinary dividend per share at current levels. With results slightly better than City forecasters had feared, the shares rose about 1% to 199.7p during late trading on Tuesday. Operating profit was £12.3bn, comfortably above the top of the range set by the company last May. Vodafone guided that profit next year would be between £12bn and £12.8bn. Revenue from internet connections rose 13.8%, while major emerging markets remained buoyant, with India up nearly 11% and Turkey up 17%. Vodafone said it would continue investing to build video-quality networks across Europe so that it could manage the high demand for data from smartphones, and extend 4G coverage across 40% of its networks in its top five European markets by March next year.
